overview.short: Elizabethkingia anophelis is a Gram-negative, aerobic, non-motile, non-fermenting rod increasingly recognised as a cause of healthcare-associated bloodstream and respiratory infections.
overview.clinical_context: Frequently linked to hospital outbreaks and infections in immunocompromised or critically ill patients; species-level identification often requires MALDI-TOF MS or molecular methods.

species_markers.notes: Indole positivity is common and supports Elizabethkingia when paired with oxidase positivity and non-fermenter profile.
A consistent negative nitrate pattern can support differentiation from some other non-fermenters.
Non-fermenter profile is central for correct placement.

common_confusions.reason: Historically overcalled due to database limitations; requires MALDI-TOF MS library quality or molecular methods for accurate separation.
Closely related environmental organisms with overlapping phenotypes; species separation often not reliable by biochem alone.

when_to_question_identification: Oxidase-negative or indole-negative results reduce confidence and suggest alternative non-fermenters.
Multiple sugars reported Positive suggests a fermenter and argues strongly against Elizabethkingia.
Definitive species assignment without MALDI-TOF MS or molecular methods should be treated cautiously.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Best practical route for reliable species-level identification within Elizabethkingia.
Useful when MALDI-TOF confidence is low or for outbreak confirmation.
Can support genus placement but is often insufficient for species resolution.
